children.subject: Also, a relationship with 162 would also be nice. Thanks again.

history.content:
EECS 149 covers embedded/cyber-physical systems, which basically means systems that typically have low processing power and/or energy requirements, and that interface with the real world through sensors and actuators. Examples we talked about in class were the computers in parking garage gates, RC drones, security cameras, etc.

Since this is Berkeley, the way that EECS 149 covers this subject is very theoretical. When I took this class, we spent a lot of time on the theory of finite state machines (turns out they can be done a lot more rigorously than in CS 61C and EECS 151). We also covered some operating systems and networking concepts at a high level, although not as in-depth as CS 162 or 168 would go.

Most people who take EECS 149 don't do it for the lecture content, but rather for the labs and project. The labs in 149 will give you a taste of what programming a microcontroller without a lot of helpful abstractions is like, and also have you do some tasks with wheeled robots that are a bit like the EE 16B car, but less frustrating. For the project, you can essentially choose anything you want that is somewhat related to embedded systems, but if you use hardware/software frameworks from the previous labs it will be easier for the course staff to help you. For what it's worth, I found the 149 project to be one of my favorite things that I worked on in college.

The course was retooled as of Fall 2018 and so those slides you're looking at may not be the best resource. In my opinion, looking at the lab descriptions / past final projects from Fall 2018/2019 is probably the best way to see if the course is for you.

I wouldn't describe the course as really covering digital/analog connections. Although the idea of measuring analog inputs is covered at some point, it's all very theoretical. You may need to learn a bit about analog-to-digital conversion and vice versa for your project, depending on what you decide to do. If you're really interested in digital/analog connections, maybe consider taking EE 120/123, or EE 140 when Prof. Pister teaches it.

Finally, in regards to how 149 relates to 162, I think that 149 is a much gentler introduction to some of the same topics covered in 162. 162 expects you to already be comfortable programming in C, even though you can make it through CS 61C without ever really reaching that level of comfort. If you take 149 in between, the labs and project should make you a lot better at programming in C without the pace of 162. Additionally, topics like scheduling, interrupt handling, and networking from 149 will show up again in 162, and you might appreciate already having studied them.

Hope this was helpful!

children.subject:
In Fall 2018, the workload came from problem sets, labs, and the final project. Problem sets were on the easy side, not very long, and were released less frequently than once a week. Labs were ostensibly three hours a week, but I would usually come in for two to three extra hours to finish them (however, I have always been slow at finishing labs, so this may be different for you). The final project took the place of labs for the last six or so weeks of the semester. Depending on how much work you put into the project, you can expect to spend anywhere between ten to forty hours a week on it, but it's very much up to you. The good thing about having an open-ended project spec is that you can always abandon parts of your project that turn out to be too difficult. There was also no final exam, so the project was the only thing to focus on towards the end of the semester.

EECS 149 was overall much less work than CS 162. In CS 162, the workload is always at least at a "medium" level, and frequently ramps up to "hard." There are also three projects, all of which have rigorous specifications that have to be met.

How much work was involved in the course in general? I was planning on doing 162 over the summer, and I didn't really know these courses had overlap. I've already taken 61c, but if this course is not as much in workload like 162, I would be even more interested in taking it. Thanks!

I can't really answer this unfortunately since I haven't taken 106A/B, but I think figuring out what your goals are for the future may help you decide --- do you want to do another big project, or learn some more theory? Although C128 fulfills the design requirement, it's not really a design/project class (it just has a lot of labs). But it does cover some pretty fundamental topics.
Thanks for in-depth answer! I am curious cuz I have taken 162 and 106A/B, is it worth to take 149 again? I am deciding between 149 and c128 and leanning toward 128 atm.

history.content:
Can someone give an understanding of what 149 covers, and what I would be expected to learn? I dont really understand it from just looking at the first lecture slides from 2016, and im interested in this course. Is it digital-analog connections? 

Thanks.
